meta.title: Email Attraction: Get What You Want Every Time You Hit Send
meta.author: Kim Arnold

parts.title: The Value of Essential Email Skills
parts.body: Kim Arnold's book on becoming better at email communication is crucial because many spend years (six on average) buried in their inbox. With little training, people struggle with inefficient emails that waste time and cause frustration. Good news—email can be incredibly effective, saving you time if done correctly. The book aims to help you become "The Big Email Enchilada," turning your email skills into a superpower to cut down those six years to even two or one by improving your communication strategy.

parts.title: Avoid Emotional Emails & Effective Email Communication
parts.body: Avoid emotional emails: Before sending emails when emotional, wait at least an hour to calm down. Consider if the email will get desired results or just appease immediate feelings. Read aloud to check if you'd say it face-to-face and get impartial advice to avoid unnecessary conflict. Effective Communication Tips: Consider the recipient's perspective; think about their style and preferences. Use the three Ws: Who you're writing to, What you want, and Why they should care. Create a two-way conversation to engage your reader and avoid being a "party bore". Use clear and engaging language rather than stiff language to connect.

parts.title: Emails and Visual Appeal - Drawing Parallels with Gourmet Cuisine
parts.body:
How Emails are Like Gourmet Meals

Fancy chefs have a way of making dishes visually appealing before you taste them - your emails should do the same. Just like we judge food visually, readers judge emails by how they look at first glance. A messy email is like a greying steak; unappealing and forgettable. To make emails attractive, create spaces and make them easy to read with short sentences and paragraphs. This attracts readers and helps them focus on your important message.

The Power of White Space in Emails

Just like a cavernous lobby, white space in your emails creates a sense of calm and importance. Too many words create chaos and overwhelm - it feels like climbing a "word wall." Short sentences and generous spacing make messages clear and leave room for important information. This makes your emails engaging and easier to handle, turning your writing into a more effective communication tool.

parts.title: Mastering Effective Email Call-to-Actions
parts.body: The section discusses the importance of having a clear, concise, and compelling call-to-action (CTA) in your emails. It emphasizes that a CTA should ask for one thing only, be direct, offer a clear and manageable next step, include a timeframe, and ideally be short, preferably one sentence. The text provides examples of common mistakes, like being too vague or overwhelming with multiple requests, and offers solutions on how to improve them. Key tips include dividing tasks into separate emails, using numbered lists for multiple requests, and always including a strong verb and deadline.

parts.title: Proofread Before Sending
parts.body: Imagine crafting an email and being ready to hit send. Hold on! Reviewing and editing your email is crucial. A slip of the keyboard, like missing an ‘l’ in ‘public’, can lead to embarrassing typos. Research indicates typos can make us appear less intelligent. Like dating, people often judge others by their grammar, so it’s worth ensuring your email is error-free. To perfect your email, try these steps: Reading it out loud helps spot awkward phrasing or mistakes. Aim for an email length of about eighty words, focusing on the necessary. Apply the HEC Hamburger technique with a hook, explanation, and CTA. Check its appearance and use tools like Grammarly for spellcheck, but do a manual proofread too. Editing enhances your credibility and effectiveness significantly.
